respondent.name: ERICA P. JOHN FUND, INC., FKA ARCHDIOCESE OF MILWAUKEE SUPPORTING FUND, INC.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 13-317, Halliburton Company v. The Erica P. John Fund. Mr. Streett.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I believe that in Basic, Alderson Reporting Company Justice Blackmun said that there is this economic theory, but also the motivation for the Exchange Act and probability and common sense would lead to this presumption -- this rebuttable presumption.  So he wasn't relying strictly on an economic theory.  I think two or three times in the opinion, he tries to make that plain.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where is that, that it says that 18(a) is the proper --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- reference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Streett, that argument, of course, is just an argument that Basic was wrong in -- in -- in not focusing on -- on Section 18, and that's contestable.  One could say actually, they were right not to focus on Section 18, Section 9 is the closer analog. But let's put that aside.        Are you just saying Basic is wrong, or are you saying that something has changed since Basic?  Because usually that's what we look for when we decide whether to reverse a case, something that makes the question fundamentally different now than when we decided it.  And that's especially so in a case like this one where Congress has had every opportunity, and has declined every opportunity, to change Basic itself. So what has changed, in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What is your third?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You said three.  What is your third?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So -- so you are not relying anymore on the notion that the efficient markets hypothesis has been undermined.  That is not one of the three points that you're making because, essentially, I think you -- you admit this in your reply brief.  You just say Halliburton has never said that market prices -- has never contested that market prices generally respond to new material information. So you are agreeing with that, that market prices generally do respond to new material information.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but we don't have that kind of binary approach.  What we allow plaintiffs to do is to try to establish a presumption, which they do by showing that a particular market is efficient, and then Alderson Reporting Company we allow defendants to rebut that presumption. So there's no binary on/off switch.        It's actually -- it's a presumption, but it's quite dependent on the facts in a particular case as to whether there's an exception to this general rule that market prices, in fact, do generally respond to new material information.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do we know how often defendants have been successful in rebutting the presumption?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could I ask you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Isn't the -- isn't the -- it's not a question of is it rebuttable.  I thought that that's already claimed from Basic.  It's a question of when.  You're arguing that it should be rebuttable at the class certification stage.  The other side is arguing, yeah, of course it's rebuttable, but that comes in at the merits determination.  It doesn't go to the question whether there are individual issues that predominate over class issues.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I -- I understand your friend on the other side to acknowledge that the efficient market theory is not perfect, that there are situations in which events are not reflected in the market price. I understand you to acknowledge that it's accurate to some extent, but that the exceptions or the -- the extent to which it's not accurate over -- override the extent to which it is.  In other words, you're each sort of dealing with at the -- at the -- if not at the margins, you know, most of the time it's efficient; you say too much of the time it's not. How am I supposed to review the economic literature and decide which of you is correct on that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, your submission is that we should jettison the Basic test because economists now believe that the efficient market theory is not sufficient -- sufficiently accurate or true to support it.  So I thought -- I mean, you review a lot of Alderson Reporting Company the economic literature in your briefs.  I assume you wanted me to look at it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Could you explain --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In a class action, how do you prove loss causation without proving price impact?  I know that there are some individual cases with individual misrepresentations that have a different form of loss causation.  But I'm talking exclusively on a -- in a class.  How do you prove loss -- proximate cause or loss causation without proving price impact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but that makes no sense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Because if they relied on their statement, then that's -- they have to prove loss causation in the same way that the class does. It's only if they're relying on a separate statement, which isn't part of the class, that would entitle them to a different calculation of loss causation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: With the same misstatement at issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then how is such a plaintiff's claim typical of the class?  You have -- you Alderson Reporting Company admitted that the 23(a) factors are met, commonality and typicality.  Well, if one is a member of this class that says, we didn't rely individually, but we did rely on the marketplace as being -- as having integrity, if you have someone to whom a direct representation was made, that person is not a proper member of this class as a discrete question, not one common to the class, not one typical.  The typical investor in a Basic class is somebody who no representation was made to that person directly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you -- can -- to take a totally different case, just thinking of the announcement of the opinion I had, is a contract case. We'll say it's the treaty that we're talking about.  And a group of plaintiffs say:  We, Your Honor, would like to show that the way that Argentina treated us was Alderson Reporting Company unfair under the treaty.  All right.  And the other side says:  Well, what we think it's fair; we don't think the treaty covers this. Now, what we have here is a common issue. So we don't have to decide, to judge who's right.  We've just noticed it was common issue.  And so they make their case, at least prima facie, that they have a side and the other side will rebut it on the merits. Well, similarly, here, they're saying:        We don't have to show that the markets incorporate every piece of information.  We think they incorporate this information, and itâ€™s a general rule, they do incorporate most information. The other side wants to show they didn't incorporate this.  That's fine.  It's a common issue. We'll decide it at the trial.  All we're trying to say is, is it a common issue, and it's not a red herring to throw in whether the markets incorporate information because normally they do, period.  Now, what's wrong with what I said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Now, we've required them to be considered because --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's certainly not the rule -- it's certainly not the rule that every -- every issue that is common has -- has to be decided at the preliminary -- or I'm sorry, must be left to the merits. I mean, as you point out, the very issue of whether the market is efficient is something that could be decided for everybody at the merits stage, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Streett, there's a -- there's a real difference with respect to those issues and I think that this was really what Amgen said.  It said that when you rule on those things, it essentially splits up the class so that different members of the class are left in very different positions; but that when you rule on a question like materiality, which leaves all members of the class in the exact same position, either with a viable claim or with no claim, and it doesn't split the class in the way that the efficient markets theory do, that's the difference. Alderson Reporting Company And here -- and this goes back to Justice Sotomayor's question -- I just don't see how this splits the class at all, because if you can't prove price impact, you can't prove loss causation and everybody's claims die.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I think that the -- that the difference is that even if you don't have market efficiency and so you lose the ability to bring the -- a claim with the fraud-on-the-market presumption, you might still have an individual reliance claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Finish your sentence. "And that cannot" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would you address briefly the position taken by the law professors, I call it the midway position, that says there should be an event study.  That might not take care of your first two arguments of the narrow construction of 10(b)(5), and the question of presumptions, but it does seem to me to be a substantial answer to your economic analysis to the -- to the challenge you make to the economic premises of the Basic decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Am -- am I correct -- and this would be more of a question for your friend representing the Respondent.  Am I correct that, even under the -- the Basic framework, at the merits stage there has to be something that looks very much like an event study.  Am I correct about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And so then the question would be since you're going to have to have it anyway, why not have it at the class certification stage.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't see how this is a midpoint.  If you're going to require proof of price Alderson Reporting Company impact, why not do away with market efficiency?  The whole premise of the other economic theory that you rely on is that the market efficiency is irrelevant.  Some information impacts the market, whether efficient or not, and some doesn't, whether efficient or not.  I think that's the basic economic argument the other side's making, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why bother with Basic at all if we're going to do what you're suggesting --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- turn the -- turn the class certification into a full-blown merits hearing on whether loss causation has been proven?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell me, based on your experience, compare the -- the cost, the extent of time, the difficulty of showing under Basic the efficient -- that there is an efficient market, and compare and contrast that with undertaking an event study.  Is the latter much more costly, much more time-consuming?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, how hard is it to show that the New York Stock Exchange is an efficient market?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So I would think the event study they are talking about would be a lot more difficult and laborious to demonstrate than market efficiency in a typical case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What happens if the -- if the plaintiffs say, Your Honor, I have 5,000 people here, all of whom bought the stock on the New York Stock Exchange between March 15 and April 15, and as far as people who had other kinds of reliance, we'll bring a separate case about them later.  But everybody in this case bought on the New York Stock Exchange and our theory of this case is that the stock exchange did absorb the information and the price went up and then went down. Alderson Reporting Company Now, what -- what reason is there for purposes of certification to go beyond the efficient market?  Is it good enough?  I mean, why not?  They all bought on the exchange.  It's not an irrelevancy. Everybody would have to say it's certainly relevant to the case and they all have the issue in common.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why go into the event study?  Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Of course that's true. Indeed, that's the defense.  The defense is, well, Your Honor, here it didn't.  And the plaintiffs say, you're right; we think it did, but if he's right and it didn't, he wins.  But you have to concede if they're right, you win. So why is that -- I don't understand why that is an appropriate issue.  I can -- I don't understand still.  Maybe it's the same.  Why is that an appropriate issue at the certification stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How many -- how many of these cases -- what percentage of these cases continue once there has been class certification?  Do you have any idea?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Very few.  Once you get the class certified, the case is over, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I see that and I understand that.  But that still strikes me as a different legal issue, and your answer is, well, we decide other things at the class certification stage. Now, I might put in parentheses:  Which don't belong there. So if -- why are we deciding any of -- why, in other words?  I still have my question, why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you a question about these event studies to which you referred?  How accurately can they distinguish between the effect of the -- the effect on price of the facts contained in a disclosure and an irrational reaction by the market, at least temporarily, to the facts contained in the disclosure?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Boies.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What do you make of Section -- what do you make of Section 203 of the PSLRA, which says that "Nothing in this Act or the amendments made by this Act shall be deemed to create or ratify any implied private right of action"?  Do you think that was a ratification of Basic?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did we refer to Section 203 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- in connection with that dictum?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think maybe we didn't know about it, as the parties here seemingly did not know about it.  I don't think it was cited in the briefs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course.  But -- but to act on the assumption that the courts are going to do what they've been doing is quite different from approving what the courts have been doing.  As I understand the history of these things, there was one side that wanted to overrule Basic and the other side that wanted to endorse Basic, and they did neither one. They simply enacted a law that assumed that the courts Alderson Reporting Company were going to continue Basic.  I don't see that that is -- is necessarily a ratification of it.  It's just an acknowledgment of reality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Boies, I don't know that I fully understood your point in your brief as to why proving price impact was so difficult.  Is it equal to proving market efficiency?  Is it less burdensome, more burdensome?  Why can't it be done at the class certification stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And the question I asked your adversary:  If we believe price impact is necessary, why keep Basic if we're going to put it in a class certification?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But why -- why couldn't that same showing be made under the law professors' theory of an event study at the certification stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: For each -- for each one of -- of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Oh, each day.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But even if Basic did not rely on economic theory, and there is a dispute on that -- I think the opinion is not quite clear on that one way or the other -- if later economic theories show that the market doesn't react in the way Basic assumed it automatically did, then certainly Congress would not wish to foreclose the Court from considering that new evidence if it was a strong, clear and convincing, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But, Mr. Boies, to say that false representation affects the market price is quite different from saying that it affects the market price almost immediately, and it's hard to see how the Basic theory can be sustained unless it does affect the market price almost immediately in what Basic described as an efficient market.  Isn't that true?  Why should someone who purchased the stock on the day, shortly, you know, an hour or two after the disclosure, be entitled to recovery if in that particular market there is some lag time in incorporating the new information?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the Petitioners say that this has produced a whole new genre of investors that are quite different from the fellow that's sitting at home reading the Wall Street Journal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And your theory doesn't seem to take that into account.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you're saying that the events -- that the law professors' event study theory is flawed, then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I didn't understand what you just said.  Are you saying there are not categories of investors who might say to themselves, You know what? There is a possibility that the price of this stock on this particular day might be artificially inflated by Alderson Reporting Company some statement that was made in the past that isn't true, but I'm going to buy it anyway because I still think it's either -- it's undervalued or because there are some other statistics regarding the market that tell me that this price is going to go up. You tell me that there are -- there are not large categories of investors who think that way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I ask you about the rebuttable presumption, Mr. Boies?  You agree that the Basic is a presumption and that it can be rebutted, but you say that's a question for the merits. What difference does it make at what stage the rebuttal is allowed?  What practical difference does Alderson Reporting Company it make if the inquiry is made at the certification stage rather than the merits stage?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You don't dispute -- I'm sorry -- you don't dispute though, that you usually don't get to the merits stage once the classes have been certified, do you?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where -- where is certification in that timeline?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Boies, you've said that -- that a lot of class certification motions are denied.  I had thought that your friend said that that is very rare except in the Second Circuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did I hear that wrong, or -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- is he wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, my question along the same lines is:  If the misrepresentation is established, from that category of cases, are there many that are still not certified?  Because that would be inconsistent with your whole theory that the market is almost always efficient.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought there were two questions, and I don't know that you've really answered the two.  I thought your colleague was talking about less than 1 percent, whatever the figure was, is of cases that were certified as classes, how many go to trial.  You said something different, which is that not every class is certified. Do you have a percentage for the amount -- the number -- for that number?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you know any article that talks about that -- those numbers?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Boise, you and I both agree that the PSLRA assumes Basic.  Now, we differ on, you know, what that means, but it does assume it. What -- and -- and so those previsions would -- would sort of be useless if Basic were entirely overruled. What if we adopted the professors' -- what, Basic writ small, if -- if we adopted their approach, would those provisions of the PSLRA still be effective?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sorry to interrupt your train of thought, but were the feasibility and prevalence of event studies something that was around when Basic was decided?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could you explain how the requirement that Basic imposed of proving publicity at the certification stage is consistent with the Court's theory in Amgen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do you think that's a realistic -- that that is something that's likely to happen in other than extremely rare cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, that's -- that's what's nagging at me that I don't fully understand.  It may be elementary, but if we had a case where all the plaintiffs had, in fact, and every one in the class had bought on the New York Stock Exchange at such and such a period, then I guess in principle neither would be appropriate for the classification stage -- Alderson Reporting Company certification stage.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Neither would be appropriate for the certification stage.  You wouldn't have to prove efficient markets; all you would have to do is allege them; because, after all, if they do exist then the reliance element is proved subject to rebuttal; and if the rebuttal wins, it's not.  And that's not a question if it's all in common, it's all in common. That's -- that's the conceptual point I haven't quite understood.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If we had a class, they all conceded that they bought it on the market at the same time, had no information, then it would go to the later stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, can I just -- can I ask a more general question?  You're representing the SEC here, the principal regulators of the securities markets and the securities industry.  So if -- I guess it's a two-part question.  If Basic were overruled, what is -- what is the view as to what -- how that would affect the securities industry and how it would affect individual decision making with respect to securities? And same question for, if the law professors' position was adopted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If the -- if the SEC brings a fraud action, can it -- can it rely on the -- on the market theory, fraud-on-the-market theory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you get to part two of Justice Kagan's question, which is what is your view of the -- of the consequences if we adopt the law professors' view?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Streett, you have 5 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many of those drop out at the summary judgment stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Whatever it might have been at the beginning, given the most recent legislation, Congress took a look at the 10(b)(5) action and it made a lot of changes.  It made pleading requirements.  It's difficult to say that this -- Congress would have legislated all these constraints if it thought there was no action to begin with.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is to prevent now a defendant from going in after the efficient market is shown, and saying, well, we have our event study; and our event study shows that this particular piece of Alderson Reporting Company information had no impact, and therefore they are not going to be able to prove reliance by just relying upon efficient markets; and therefore don't certify the class.  Why couldn't you do that right now under Basic?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, is there anything -- is there any court that said, no, you can't do that; we forbid you even though it says in Basic that you're allowed to rebut?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So your preference would be to make the plaintiff bear the burden or just for defendants to be able to rebut the price impact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- at a class certification?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
